ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: lots of russian literature and advanced grammar!
I developed better communication skills in Russian, a better understanding of grammar, such as tenses and numerals, and a lot of knowledge about 19-century Russian history.

Reading and speaking/summarizing/discussion skills in Russian, particularly of history texts. Also studied grammar (participles, gerunds, imperatives, numbers) and certain vocabulary, focusing on common verbs.
I advanced my Russian skills significantly.
I gained a very solid understanding of 19th century history, improved my vocabulary and grammar and have become able to read Russian literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The entire course is full of strengths. I'd say the content, teaching, and just overall flexibility is the strength. Constantine is one of the nicest people I've ever met, and there's no one better to teach such a packed course in such a small amount of time.

The strengths are the small class size, high student engagement, and great lectures and explanations of the material. I do not see any huge weaknesses in this course, everything was great and I learned a lot! Maybe it would be better to travel to Russia like in previous years before the Covid breakout to get more experience communicating with native speakers and get to know the authentic Russian culture.

Strengths: Lots of engaging material, relevant grammar/vocabulary, many opportunities for cultural engagement/exploration
Weaknesses: Lack of balance for students with more vs less Russian language ability; students more fluent in Russian tend to dominate class
--> maybe have more advanced students be more aware of this?

The professor is great and very helpful. I liked how the texts were utilized and integrated into the curriculum. It could be a bit repetitive, but this may have been exacerbated because the class was online.

Strengths: vocabulary incorporated into Russian history
Weakness: honestly not much-- always having to write a history summary felt a bit monotonous, though.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely if you want to continue learning Russian. I think Russian literature and just being able to read coherently is inherent to Russian culture itself and this course teaches you a lot about that!

I would definitely recommend this course to other students since it helps to improve the language skill very efficiently in a short amount of time. It takes the language skill to a higher level and helps to learn the history of Russian in the 19th century in a very detailed and fun way.
Yes! Given you have taken Russian classes up to L4 or have equivalent experience. Good class to improve reading and discussion skills.
Yes. If Russian is something you are passionate about you should absolutely take this course. However, you need to be committed to the language.
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone looking to improve their Russian and learn more about Russian history.
